This game allows you to control your own player in a fast paced 6 minute games, either on 3v3 or 5v5 games.

There are tons of things you can do from passing, to dribbling, to taking advantage of the walls surrounding the pitch to create plays. It resembles games like FIFA Street except that passing is the only way to get far while dribbling is there to gain an extra second so you can choose the best available passing option.

The game probably released a bit too early and launched with bugs, network issues and exploits that affected the way the game was supposed to be played. Since then it has gone a long way and it is now in its most balanced state and network issues are a thing of the past. 

The gameplay is fluid and very fun, especially if you find like-minded teammates to take full advantage of the link up plays. Even if you find yourself in a game full of random teammates that you can't seem to work with don't worry about it, the game ends after 6 minutes or after being down by a 4 goal difference. 

Unfortunately it has lost a lot of players in the months since the release either because the game might not be for everyone or because it had these early issues. However it is VERY far from dead and you can find a game within 20 seconds most of the time. I am predicting that at some point in the game's life cycle it will go F2P. In any case, the game is not dead at all and if you buy it now you will zero trouble playing within seconds from queueing. 

If you are someone who enjoys football games where you only control your own player you should definitely give it a try. It is fairly priced, has a loyal playerbase and most people are cooperative. You will meet likeminded people to play with very fast and you will have a lot of fun. The fast pace of the game, the fluidity and the short duration of each games ensures that you will have fun in short bursts or you will suffer for only a few minutes before a bad game ends. The comparison to Rocket League is fair from this perspective so if you are a Rocket League player who enjoys and understands football chances are you will enjoy the game. You can easily play it on your controller  but also on mouse and keyboard which is what I personally prefer.

REMATCH is the love of your life in high school. You wait for it, dream about it, crave it, and when it finally arrives, youâ€™re overwhelmed with excitement.

When I saw the first playtest, I was the happiest man alive. At last, a sports game built entirely on skill: no Pay-to-Win, no packs, no corporate greed from EA lurking behind it. 
Just a small studio, the same publisher as Expedition 33, and a project that inspired trust. 

Then the game launched.

Since release, REMATCH has felt like that first love: it could have been perfect, if only it lasted. Youâ€™ll always think back and wonder, â€œWhat ifâ€¦?â€ What if the developers had taken a different path? 
Day one was fun, but unpolished: bugs, disconnections, crashes everywhere. They tried to patch things slowly, too slowly, and with every fix new problems appeared. 
Like with your first love, you keep fighting, telling yourself it will be fine, because â€œHey, this is the love of your life, donâ€™t waste it.â€

But then came the decision to bundle new features with fixes. Patches dragged on, cross-play was forced in, and players began to leave. I poured 600 hours into Season 0, plus 150 more during the betas. I still believe REMATCH could become the next great eSport, but the road is steep.

Community-wise, itâ€™s tough for newcomers. Most of the remaining players are either competitive teams or ego-driven veterans, which makes learning the game harder. To play well, you need vision and tactical awareness, qualities rare in a world conditioned by FIFA and arcade-style sports titles. Here, movement is deeply simulative: you must sync perfectly with teammates, press together, fill the right spaces at the right time. 
The "meta" itself demands technical mastery: knowing where to place the ball to trigger the right animation, where to pass to unlock your teammateâ€™s movement. 

This complexity could be the foundation of a true eSport, but it also risks keeping the player base small.

As a fan, the biggest issue is how static matches feel. Competitive players reset to the keeper, call the scheme, execute it. Rarely do you see someone shine with a clever dribble or an unexpected move. Watching tournaments, you often find yourself bored, skipping ahead to the next game.

Still, I believe the Game Awards nomination might shine a spotlight on REMATCH, helping rebuild its community. And I hope it wins â€œBest Sports Game.â€ Why? Because it deserves it. Itâ€™s fresh, original, and skill-based, everything a sport should be. FC is a money machine, Mario Kart isnâ€™t even a sport. REMATCH is the only title on the list that truly fits.

My hope is that winning will attract a bigger company, maybe Epic Games, to buy the IP and elevate it; just as they did with Rocket League. Because despite all its flaws, REMATCH is still great. And maybe, like the love of your life, you grow apart, live your own story, and then one day stumble back into her arms. You try again from where you left off, and maybe this time you live your best life with what you always knew was the love of your life. Youâ€™ll never know unless you try.

As a football game, it has, [i]by nature[/i], one of the most toxic communities Iâ€™ve ever encountered. I've been screamed at, insulted, sometimes in languages I don't even understand, and even received a death threat. And still, it has proven to be one of the most fun multiplayer experiences I've enjoyed in close to a decade. 

Having played this game since day 1, it is clear to me that it was not quite ready for launch when it did launch. The growing pains it went through trying to balance the most egregious "meta" that was popular the following weeks left a lot of people disappointed and frustrated, both the users of said "meta" and its victims. By now, in my opinion, the game has arrived at a point where I'd call it to be a good position in terms of balance. Sure, it still feels unfair at times, but I've noticed that a lot of times it is not because teams were inherently unfairly balanced (though sometimes they are), but that my team just didn't [i]vibe[/i] as well as the opponent's did.
When this game works, [b]it works[/b]. It takes everything, that, for me, makes football boring to watch and incredibly boring to play and just [b]yeets[/b] that out the window. The last time I got this much enjoyment out of a football game was Fifa Street for the PS2 in 2006. Accuracy, reliability, positioning and teamwork don't rely on some random stats your team is made out of (or worse how much money you spent), but on the skill and attention of every single player. While this might lead to frustration sometimes, especially in 5v5, it is even more rewarding everytime your team succeeds. 
Being a live-service title I'm not surprised that there are micro transactions and a pass. Development is an ongoing cost and it needs an ongoing revenue stream. I am pleasantly surprised however that every item in the shop or the pass is cosmetic in nature and there being no space for pay 2 win. Its cosmetics (so far) are also not extremely ridiculous or completely unfitting to its visual style (though the halloween pack was cutting it very close in my opinion). 

Taking the well-established formula of football and being the first to try and turn it into an even more engaging and fun video game experience than any one has ever tried before is not an easy task and for the most part, the team at Sloclap has exceeded all my expectations. For its price of just 25â‚¬ I fully recommend Rematch. If you're unsure, the next Steam Sale is bound to happen or you might check out third-party sellers offering an even better deal.

Rematch is what some would like to call "Rocket League but with People". But incase that doesn't clue you in to what that entails, let me explain. Rematch is a teambased football Game, focused on a speed and precison. Where just like in the game that it gets jokeingly refered to, you can shoot, and pass the ball of giant barriers that cover out of bounds areas of the playing area, allowing you to essentially include the walls in your plays. 

The potential with this game is by all means very limitless. It's competitive, it's fun with friends, it has all the right ingredients to be great. But there is just one giant flaw, one catch, that makes it hard for me to even recommend the game, no matter how much i love it.

That flaw is the execution of its ongoing development is simply not good enough. While the devs clearly care and are trying their best, the updates are consistently breaking more than they fix. We are currently stuck in a painful loop of delays and regression that is slowly eroding player trust of a dwindling player base. The caution they are takeing before adding any new features is understandable but the game is lacking in places it never should have.

In its current state, Rematch is a brilliant tech demo wrapped in a fragile package. Keep an eye on its patch notes, but maybe keep your wallet closed until the dust settles, or this flower finally blooms.

I think this game was something special and a refreshing competitive idea come to life. I really enjoyed playing it from the beta, but after seeing the meta progression though a couple of patches, I can't recommend it because of the problems with the game engine

The most similar game this is compared to is probably Rocket League, but I think that's a mistake as RL is a physics based engine, whereas this engine is the SIFU engine repurposed. After playing, you can really feel that it's more of a fighting game, and the server stability has always been awful with players' connections really make playing the game difficult. Each match is plagued by inconsistent hit detection, lag, desync, and random disconnects. Imagine playing a 1v1 fighting game without rollback frames, and this game is basically a 5v5 fighting game..

A huge point of my distaste with the game was the evolution of the Meta, and how the developers' attempts to try to shape the game to their original vision resulted in worse experiences for the general playerbase. The skill in this game is abusing the game engine mechanics before it gets patched out, and then trying to figure out the next exploit that's in the game. Compare that to Rocket League where Flip Resets were always in the game, but it wasn't until players discovered that interaction and then made it a part of the game

Here's how the Meta evolved in the short months I was playing before I decided to quit the game

1. Meta was defined by abusing a "gather ball" and "push ball" animation, making something called "the ippy slide". It was incredibly easy to pull off, and used the server desync and engine mechanics to teleport the ball while dribbling. It was very difficult to defend against, and because the tech was so easy to master, games became centered around players exploiting this desync 
[b]>devs make changes slowing player movement, reducing the distances in which a player can gather the ball, and nerfs the push ball distance[/b] 

2. Meta became a slog of defense focused turnovers. Passing became harder, and there was a lack of offensive options to skillfully beat your defender. This meta was probably the my favorite one to play because it mimics real soccer- you need accurate passing to capitalize on defense mistakes. However, this meta resulted in extremely long Over Times, with some images online showing players in the same game for 30+ minutes
[b]>devs make changes[/b] 

3. Meta returns to a fast pace, but now there's misleading animations without reliable defensive counterplay. Attacking players now spam a single button juggle that is chainable, and the defensive option is a jump to block. Missing a jump block has insane recovery time and only works about 50%, so your best option on defense is to sit, not move, and wait to see if you can get your turn to interact with the ball

Unfortunately I don't know how the devs can 'fix' this game so it becomes a game of skillful dribbling, passing, shooting, and defending. I think your $30 is spent better elsewhere

Very fun concept and gameplay, but the execution is terrible. The game was released at least 6 months too early, and as a result the entirety of season 0 (and some of S1) essentially felt like the game was still in the playtesting stage.

Movement got reworked multiple times, changing the feel of the game completely after launch, and despite these drastic changes we are STILL seeing bugs that have been in the game since the closed playtest stages. 

The game was missing core features and menu functionality for months post launch, and only now is the studio giving attention to the ranked mode, which has been a complete mess with ranks, ranking up, and matchmaking since day 1. This is of course, not even touching on the fact that solo queue is almost entirely pointless, as you'll get nowhere without competent teammates.

Development is far too slow and convoluted for a competitive multiplayer game like this, which needs to find its niche and do it well right off the bat. Further, I simply don't believe the game will last much longer. Playing on EU servers I'm regularly seeing queue times up to 3 minutes on 5v5 quickplay. Adding this on at the end because I somehow forgot to mention monetisation, but it is not good. The game costs Â£20.99 in the UK, and still comes with a full suite of paid battlepass, paid cosmetics, and premium currency. This on its own would be fine, since they need to make money to keep the lights on, but the rate of progression is some of the worst I've seen. 

Each battlepass has 3 time-gated "phases", each one filled with nodes that take 3 or 5 battlepass points to unlock, giving you one cosmetic per point. Depending on performance, you need to play 4-5 matches for one point, which means that you'll spend roughly 50-60 HOURS to complete ONE battlepass, which expires at the end of the season whether you paid for it or not. 

It's also important to mention that the battlepass has multiple paths you can take with your points, which can be nice if you only want one or two items from a path, but it also means that if those items are at the end, you need to spend your points on that entire path before reaching that singular reward. This level of grind is ridiculous, and effectively means that unless this is your main game that you play every day without fail, you won't be able to complete the battlepass and will have wasted the money you spent on it.
